sub_topic: Determine the Laplacian of a function on a manifold.
message_1: Given an n-dimensional sphere of radius r, parameterized by spherical coordinates $$(\rho, \phi_{1}, \phi_{2}, \dots, \phi_{n-1})$$ and a function $f(\rho, \phi_{1}, \phi_{2}, \dots, \phi_{n-1}) = \rho^{2} sin^{2}(\phi_{1})$, find the Laplacian of $f$ on the manifold.
message_2:
To find the Laplacian of the function $f(\rho, \phi_{1}, \phi_{2}, \dots, \phi_{n-1}) = \rho^{2} \sin^{2}(\phi_{1})$ on the n-dimensional sphere, we first need to find the Laplace-Beltrami operator in spherical coordinates. The Laplace-Beltrami operator is given by:

$$\Delta f = \frac{1}{\sqrt{g}} \sum_{i,j=1}^{n} \frac{\partial}{\partial x_i} \left( g^{ij} \sqrt{g} \frac{\partial f}{\partial x_j} \right),$$

where $g$ is the determinant of the metric tensor $g_{ij}$, and $g^{ij}$ is the inverse of the metric tensor.

For an n-dimensional sphere of radius r, the metric tensor is diagonal with elements:

$$g_{ij} = \begin{cases} r^2, & i = j = 1 \\ r^2 \sin^2(\phi_1), & i = j = 2 \\ r^2 \sin^2(\phi_1) \sin^2(\phi_2), & i = j = 3 \\ \cdots \\ r^2 \sin^2(\phi_1) \sin^2(\phi_2) \cdots \sin^2(\phi_{n-2}), & i = j = n-1 \end{cases}$$

The determinant of the metric tensor is:

$$g = \det(g_{ij}) = r^{2n} \sin^{2(n-2)}(\phi_1) \sin^{2(n-3)}(\phi_2) \cdots \sin^2(\phi_{n-2}).$$

The inverse of the metric tensor is also diagonal with elements:

$$g^{ij} = \begin{cases} \frac{1}{r^2}, & i = j = 1 \\ \frac{1}{r^2 \sin^2(\phi_1)}, & i = j = 2 \\ \frac{1}{r^2 \sin^2(\phi_1) \sin^2(\phi_2)}, & i = j = 3 \\ \cdots \\ \frac{1}{r^2 \sin^2(\phi_1) \sin^2(\phi_2) \cdots \sin^2(\phi_{n-2})}, & i = j = n-1 \end{cases}$$

Now, we can compute the Laplace-Beltrami operator for the function $f(\rho, \phi_{1}, \phi_{2}, \dots, \phi_{n-1}) = \rho^{2} \sin^{2}(\phi_{1})$:

$$\Delta f = \frac{1}{\sqrt{g}} \sum_{i,j=1}^{n} \frac{\partial}{\partial x_i} \left( g^{ij} \sqrt{g} \frac{\partial f}{\partial x_j} \right).$$

We only need to compute the terms for $i = j = 1$ and $i = j = 2$, since the function $f$ does not depend on the other coordinates.

For $i = j = 1$:

$$\frac{\partial}{\partial \rho} \left( g^{11} \sqrt{g} \frac{\partial f}{\partial \rho} \right) = \frac{\partial}{\partial \rho} \left( \frac{1}{r^2} \sqrt{g} 2\rho \sin^2(\phi_1) \right) = 2 \frac{\partial}{\partial \rho} \left( \frac{\rho \sin^2(\phi_1)}{r^2} \right) = 2 \frac{\sin^2(\phi_1)}{r^2}.$$

For $i = j = 2$:

$$\frac{\partial}{\partial \phi_1} \left( g^{22} \sqrt{g} \frac{\partial f}{\partial \phi_1} \right) = \frac{\partial}{\partial \phi_1} \left( \frac{1}{r^2 \sin^2(\phi_1)} \sqrt{g} 2\rho^2 \sin(\phi_1) \cos(\phi_1) \right) = \frac{\partial}{\partial \phi_1} \left( \frac{2\rho^2 \sin(\phi_1) \cos(\phi_1)}{r^2} \right) = -4 \frac{\rho^2 \sin(\phi_1) \cos(\phi_1)}{r^2}.$$

Therefore, the Laplacian of the function $f(\rho, \phi_{1}, \phi_{2}, \dots, \phi_{n-1}) = \rho^{2} \sin^{2}(\phi_{1})$ on the n-dimensional sphere is:

$$\Delta f = 2 \frac{\sin^2(\phi_1)}{r^2} - 4 \frac{\rho^2 \sin(\phi_1) \cos(\phi_1)}{r^2}.$$
